Simplify your tech stack and save on cost with the Content Cloud: a secure, easy-to-use platform built for the entire content lifecycle, from file creation and sharing, to co-editing, e-signature, classification, and retention. And with 1,500+ best-of-breed integrations, teams work from anywhere across all their favourite apps. Trusted by 100K+ of the world's leading organisations -- including AstraZeneca, JLL, and Nationwide -- Box has been named a Leader by all major industry analyst firms. To read the analyst reports and find out how Box customers achieve a 332% ROI, visit box.com/resources. Founded in 2005, Box is headquartered in Redwood City, CA, with offices across the United States, Canada, Europe, and Asia Pacific. 

 Protect your content  

Keep your files safe with cloud-native security and compliance capabilities like granular access controls, watermarking, and classification. Stay proactive with Box Shield's machine learning and the ability to set policies that detect threats.  

 Empower your people 

With everything from file annotations to automated tasks, teams collaborate anytime, anywhere, on any device, with people inside and outside your business.

 Connect your business  

Securely connect your content to the rest of your tech stack with 1,500+ pre-built integrations. Extend Box to meet your organisation's unique needs using developer tools and APIs.

initial_reviews.review_content:
What do you like best about Box?
We migrated over to box 4 years ago and now have over 3k users accessing box daily. The web interface is intuitive and packed with features, but in a way that allows different types of users to either take full advantage or to just use it as a content repository. It's really easy to get users in and working on your content and I particularly appreciate the solid version control and ability to see exactly what's happened/is happening with a given piece of content at any time. Box also integrates with just about anything so in addition to the baked-in features, you can link it with lots of other applications, making the whole experience very seamless. On the admin side, the controls are very straightforward; we found the initial deployment pretty easy and migrating additional data into our instance over the last 4 years has been very simple. With the new data onboarding options, I can see this would be even more straightforward for new customers to move large initial datasets. Our support team at box are helpful and friendly - I enjoy being able to discuss new ideas with them and contributing to the ongoing development of box (where I've already seen several updates related to ideas I've had or supported). Frankly, I can't recommend box enough!

What do you dislike about Box?
There's isn't anything I specifically dislike about box itself. One challenge we've had is weaning users away from the box drive interface and over to the more powerful web interface. I'm looking forward to some upcoming changes to some of the admin reports which I think are important for anyone with a bigger instance.

What problems is Box solving and how is that benefiting you?
Box allows us to collaborate seamlessly on content all around our global business. The search function (combined with tags and/or metadata) make it easy for people to find what they need and get on with their daily work with minimal fuss. The security of knowing our data are backed up in multuple locations means that we won't lose anything and the ability to assign specific sets of content to specific regions makes it easy to comply with differing client requirements (e.g. if a client requires that their data be stored only in the USA, that's possible). One very important feature for us is the solid access controls which enable different parts of our business to be firewalled from one another - a feature that realistically extends right down to invidual users. We deployed at the end of 2019 and it was a life saver during covid - our old systems would certainly not have been able to cope with such a sudden and large-scale shift in working practices. I also like the simplicity of the waterfall permissions system - it means that, with a little organisation, giving people access to the content they need stays simple and doesn't end up in a rabbit warren of user-level permissions like some other cloud storage solutions do.

What do you like best about Box?
Sharing with others and controlling the access is much better than Sharepoint. When working with a client we can share files with the client so that they can see only that file. But in Sharepoint sometimes we have to share a folder. The new canvas whiteboard feature is good. Box Notes is good, predefined layouts are perfect. For example: Meeting Agenda, project plans, Project Status, etc. The relay feature is good But not explored much. Need training material to use relay effectively

What do you dislike about Box?
Excel in Box can not be edited simultaneously, 2 people can not edit the Excel file stored in the Box. We need a Box for Windows the local machine app to open Excel. Sometimes we faced, when 2 people were working on excel updates could not save. In that scenario, we have to save it to our local drive and then upload it back to Box.

What problems is Box solving and how is that benefiting you?
The online file sharing feature is good and we have a better option to control sharing with clients.

initial_reviews.review_title: Online storage option that doesn't lie to you
initial_reviews.review_content:
What do you like best about Box?
I got 50GB of free storage with the phone I purchased. This is truly free. (unlike mega which gives 15 GB free, but the free storage you earn will expire and if your storage exceeds the 15 GB, you lose data or you have to go for a paid plan). It doesn't just disappear after a year or so. There's a limit to the size per file uploaded, but that is fine.
There is an automatic backup option for photos, but I wouldn't switch this on.
There's a pdf reader if you upload your projects in pdf format.
The starter pack will upgrade you to single file upload size of 2GB.

What do you dislike about Box?
Sometimes the upload gets stuck and you have to reupload everything again.
Videos don't stream properly at times.

What problems is Box solving and how is that benefiting you?
I think a free cloud storage offering 50GB without any ads itself is a great thing. If you want more you could go for paid packs (which are cheaper than most competitors)

initial_reviews.review_title: A Secure and Collaborative Cloud-Based Content Management Platform
initial_reviews.review_content:
What do you like best about Box?
Box takes data security seriously, employing industry-leading measures to protect your information. All data is encrypted at rest and in transit, and access controls can be configured to restrict access to authorized users only. Additionally, Box offers a variety of data residency options to ensure that your data is stored in a region that meets your compliance requirements.

Box's interface is designed to be easy to use, even for users with limited technical experience. The drag-and-drop functionality makes it simple to upload and organize files, and the search function allows you to quickly find the information you need. Additionally, Box offers a variety of resources, including tutorials and videos, to help you get the most out of the platform.

Box integrates with a variety of third-party applications, making it easy to incorporate it into your existing workflow. For example, you can use Box to automatically save files from Microsoft Office 365 or Google Workspace. Additionally, you can embed Box files into presentations, websites, and other documents.

What do you dislike about Box?
It has been observed that slow response times from Box's customer support team. This can be frustrating if you need help with a technical issue or if you have a question about your account. However, Box has been working to improve its customer support, and there are now a number of different ways to get help, including phone, email, and live chat.

It has limited storage space. Msuct increase some storage space foe better user experience.

What problems is Box solving and how is that benefiting you?
I deal with vast amounts of text and code data, which requires secure and reliable storage solutions. Box's cloud-based storage infrastructure provides a secure repository for my training data and generated responses. The encryption at rest and in transit ensures that my sensitive information remains protected from unauthorized access.

What do you like best about Box?
I like the following things about Box:

It is a cloud-based file-sharing and collaboration platform. This means that I can access my files from anywhere, on any device.
It is secure. Box uses a variety of security features to protect my files, including encryption, two-factor authentication, and role-based access control.
It is easy to use. The interface is intuitive and easy to learn, even for people with no technical experience.
It is scalable. Box can grow with my business, so I don't have to worry about switching to a new file-sharing platform as I grow.
It is integrated with other applications. Box integrates with a variety of other applications, such as Microsoft Office, Google Drive, and Salesforce. This makes it easy to share files with others and collaborate on projects.
Here are some specific features of Box that I like:

The ability to share files with others. I can easily share files with my team members, clients, and partners.
The ability to collaborate on files. I can work on files with others in real-time.
The ability to search for files. I can easily find files by name, content, or date.
The ability to set permissions for files. I can control who has access to my files and what they can do with them.
The ability to automate tasks. I can automate tasks, such as file sharing and notifications.
Overall, I think Box is a great file-sharing and collaboration platform. It is secure, easy to use, and scalable. I would definitely recommend it to businesses of all sizes.

What do you dislike about Box?
Here are some things that I dislike about Box:

The pricing can be expensive for businesses with a lot of users. The pricing plans are based on the number of users and the amount of storage space you need. This can be expensive for businesses with a lot of users or who need a lot of storage space.
The mobile app can be slow at times. The mobile app is a great way to access your files on the go. However, it can be slow at times, especially when you are trying to access large files.
The search function can be inaccurate. The search function is not always accurate. This can be frustrating when you are trying to find a specific file.
The user interface can be cluttered. The user interface is not always the most intuitive. This can be frustrating for users who are not familiar with Box.
The integration with other applications can be limited. Box integrates with a variety of other applications, but the integration is not always perfect. This can be frustrating for users who want to use Box with their favorite applications.
Overall, I think Box is a great file-sharing and collaboration platform. However, there are some things that I dislike about it. The pricing can be expensive, the mobile app can be slow, the search function can be inaccurate, the user interface can be cluttered, and the integration with other applications can be limited.

What problems is Box solving and how is that benefiting you?
Box solves a variety of problems for businesses, including:

File sharing: Box makes it easy to share files with others, both inside and outside of your organization. This can be helpful for collaborating on projects, sharing presentations, or sending documents to clients.
File storage: Box provides secure storage for your files, so you can rest assured that they are safe and accessible.
File collaboration: Box allows you to collaborate on files in real time, so you can work with others on the same document at the same time. This can save time and improve productivity.
Data security: Box uses a variety of security features to protect your files, including encryption, two-factor authentication, and role-based access control. This helps to prevent unauthorized access to your files.
Compliance: Box is compliant with a variety of industry standards, so you can be sure that your files are stored in a secure and compliant way.

initial_reviews.review_title: This Cloud is used to Sharing Files Made Easy
initial_reviews.review_content:
What do you like best about Box?
Yo, so I've been using Box.com for a while now, and it's pretty dope!

What I like best about Box.com is the seamless file sharing.  Sharing documents and files with friends and colleagues is a piece of cake. No more wrestling with email attachments or dealing with confusing permissions. You just send a link, and boom, they're in. It's like having a secret handshake to your digital stuff. Plus, the collaboration features are a game-changer. Working on projects with my crew is smooth as butter, and it's all in real-time. No more waiting for the latest version to arrive in my inbox. Box.com just makes teamwork feel like a breeze. 

What do you dislike about Box?
What I'm not too thrilled about with Box.com is the limitations of the free plan.  It's understandable that they need to make a buck, but the free version can feel a bit restricted, especially if you're handling a lot of files. If you need more storage or features, you'll have to shell out some cash. But hey, I guess it's the price for the convenience. And to be honest, it's not crazy expensive. So, it's more like a minor gripe rather than a deal-breaker.

What problems is Box solving and how is that benefiting you?
Box cloud tackles file organization chaos, making my digital life a breeze. No more scattered files; it's like having a virtual librarian. Sharing and collaborating? Super easy. It's my trusty online sidekick.
